title: 115_hr1957
content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress acknowledges that bullying and harassment in schools can harm students' physical and mental health, hinder learning, and lead to negative outcomes such as high dropout rates and academic underachievement. These behaviors create a climate of fear and disrespect that impairs students' ability to participate in educational opportunities. Bullying and harassment in schools negatively impact students' ability to learn and participate in educational opportunities. Behaviors include hitting, name-calling, intimidation, social exclusion, and sending offensive messages through electronic communications. Schools with anti-bullying policies see increased reporting and teacher intervention, reducing incidents. Students are often targeted for bullying. Some students experience bullying based on various factors like race, gender, and disability. This includes relational aggression or psychological bullying. Some young people face bullying and harassment based on factors like race, gender, disability, and more. This includes relational aggression, which harms individuals by damaging relationships or causing social acceptance issues. Interventions aim to create a positive and safe school environment. Interventions to address bullying and harassment aim to create a positive and safe school climate, minimizing exclusionary discipline policies like suspensions and expulsions. Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS) and restorative practices are effective in preventing students from being pushed out or diverted to the juvenile justice system. Evidence-based discipline policies like PBIS and restorative practices can reduce suspensions and expulsions, preventing students from being pushed out to the juvenile justice system. 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying in schools, prompting calls for leadership and action from students, parents, educators, and policymakers. According to a poll, 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying in schools, leading to calls for leadership and action from students, parents, educators, and policymakers. SEC. 3. SAFE SCHOOLS IMPROVEMENT. This section adds a new part to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to address bullying and harassment in public schools. The purpose is to tackle bullying and harassment conduct among students. Anti-bullying policies are to be implemented. The term 'bullying' in this part includes cyber-bullying. States receiving grants must require local educational agencies to establish policies preventing severe, persistent, or pervasive conduct that limits a student's participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The policies required under paragraph (1) address bullying and harassment that severely impacts a student's participation or creates a hostile educational environment through various forms of aggression or intimidation. The policies required under paragraph (1) prohibit bullying or harassment based on a student's race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. The policies prohibit bullying or harassment based on a student's actual or perceived characteristics such as race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, or any other defining traits determined by the educational agency. The local educational agency's discipline policies prohibit bullying or harassment based on a student's characteristics such as race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, or any other defining traits determined by the agency. Annual notice must be provided to students, parents, and educational professionals regarding the prohibited conduct. The local educational agency must provide annual notice describing prohibited conduct in its discipline policies and grievance procedures for complaints. The local educational agency must provide annual notice describing prohibited conduct in its discipline policies and grievance procedures for complaints, including the officials responsible for receiving complaints and timelines for resolution. Additionally, the agency must collect annual data on the incidence and frequency of incidents. The local educational agency must collect annual data on the incidence and frequency of incidents related to prohibited conduct, ensuring accuracy and completeness. This data should be publicly reported at both the school and agency levels. The local educational agency must collect accurate and complete data on prohibited conduct at the school level and publicly report it. Positive and preventative approaches to school discipline should be encouraged to minimize student removal from instruction and avoid disproportionate punishment. State reports are required from the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant under this title, in collaboration with the State educational agency. The report should include information from local educational agencies on prohibited conduct and outline the State's plans to support local efforts in addressing such conduct. The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of programs to combat bullying in schools, including assessing the effectiveness of requirements and parent involvement. The Commissioner for Education Statistics will collect data on the incidence of prohibited conduct in states. The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of programs to combat bullying in schools, including assessing the effectiveness of requirements and parent involvement. The Commissioner for Education Statistics will collect data on the incidence of prohibited conduct in states, subject to independent review. The Secretary will submit a report to the President and Congress every two years, including evaluation findings, data collected, and information submitted by states. "SEC. 4705. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS." The text states that federal and state nondiscrimination laws, including title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, are not invalidated or limited by the current part. The obligations under this part are additional to those imposed by existing laws. The obligations under this part are in addition to those imposed by existing federal and state nondiscrimination laws, including title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Nothing in this part shall affect free speech and expression laws. The obligations under this part are additional to existing federal and state nondiscrimination laws, including title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. This part does not impact free speech and expression laws. The text introduces a rule of construction stating that states or local entities can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with the Safe Schools Improvement Act. This rule is part of the Act's provisions, which include anti-bullying policies, state reports, evaluation, and the impact on other laws.
